Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Biomimetic Super-Resolving Electrically Small Antenna Arrays

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to fundamentally advance our understanding of super-resolving electrically small antenna arrays using biomimetic design concepts. The approach is to use the analogies between acoustical and electromagnetic systems and develop miniaturized antenna arrays that mimic the hyperacute sense of directional hearing observed in certain small vertebrates and insect species.

Intellectual Merit: This project seeks to address a fundamental challenge in the area of electrically small antennas using a previously unexplored approach. This work is expected to introduce super-resolving capabilities that have not been achieved from conventional small antenna arrays. These capabilities can bring a whole new level of functionality to small wireless systems and enable applications that are not currently feasible.

Broader Impacts: This project is expected to have a significantly positive impact on society and economy by revolutionizing how we address challenges in areas such as microwave medical imaging, wireless networks, radar systems, sensors, radio-frequency identification, and radio-frequency devices for assisting the disabled and visually impaired. Educational goals of this work are intimately linked to research goals and include facilitation of engineering-oriented professional development of middle-school and high-school science teachers, integration of research activities into the teaching of science and engineering at the K-12, undergraduate, and graduate levels, involvement of under-represented students in research, and development and broad dissemination of research-based educational materials. Indirectly, these educational activities are expected to have a positive impact on increasing the number of female students who pursue engineering and minority students who pursue graduate studies in electrical engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits:

Achieving significant directional sensitivities from electrically-small antenna arrays is one of the fundamental challenges in the area of electrically-small antennas. We investigated addressing this challenge by mimicking the solutions that nature provides for a similar problem. Specifically, an analogy exists between this problem and the hyperacute sense of directional hearing of certain insects. In this project, we investigated the use of these biomimetic concepts to develop super-resolving electrically small antenna arrays and investigated some of their applications. The specific outcomes of this project are categorized into four categories as outlined below:

 

1)     Developing two-element biomimetic antenna arrays (BMAAs). In this project, we first developed two-element BMAAs that directly mimic the auditory system of the parasitoid fly Ormia Ochracea. We demonstrated that such antennas demonstrate enhanced angular sensitivities compared to their conventional counterparts having similar dimensions. Subsequently, we developed a method for designing optimum BMAAs that achieve enhanced angular sensitivities while extracting the maximum available power from an incoming wave. Finally, we developed a comprehensive theoretical method for synthesizing two-element BMAAs. This generalized synthesis procedure can be used to identify all possible implementations of a two-element BMAA that uses a given set of receiving elements.

 

2)     Developing multi-element biomimetic antenna arrays. We also expanded the concept of biomimetic antenna array design to electrically-small antennas that use more than two receiving elements. This is important because in many applications, such as direction finding systems, arrays with more than two elements are used. For example, in a direction finding system, a multi-element antenna array can be used to detect the direction of arrival of a signal of interest in three dimensions. To enable the utilization of the benefits of the BMAA concept in such systems, we expanded our theoretical and experimental investigation of the BMAA concept to multi-element antenna arrays whose elements for linear or triangular baselines. Through a set of theoretical analyses and experiments, we demonstrated that the enhanced angular sensitivities that were observed in two-element BMAAs can be expanded to such multi-element BMAAs.

 

3)     Development of techniques for enhancing the bandwidths of biomimetic electrically-small antenna arrays. One of the limitations of electrically-small BMAAs is their relatively narrow bandwidths. To address this challenge, we developed two techniques that can be used to effectively enhance the overall bandwidth of a two-element BMAA. The first technique involved the development of non-Foster BMAAs. We demonstrated that using reactive elements with negative values (i.e., negative inductors and capacitors) in the design of a two-element BMAA allows for significantly increasing the bandwidth of the antenna. We also designed and simulated such non-Foster BMAAs. The second technique involved the design of a two-element, electronically-tunable BMAA. Specifically, we developed and experimentally demonstrated a two-element BMAA whose response can be tuned over a wide bandwidth using a single variable capacitor.

 

4)     Investigating applications of biomimetic electrically-small antenna arrays. In addition to the development of various two- and multi-element BMAAs, we also investigated some of the applications of such antennas. Specifically, we examined the applications of BMAAs in designing direction finding systems, development of angle-sensing infrared detectors, and capacity enhancement of MIMO communications systems. In each of these cases, we demonstrated that the use of BMAAs can offer advantages that cannot be readily achieved using conventional antenna design techniques. Our investigations in each of these areas resulted in initiation of three different research projects with the goals of investigating the applications of BMAAs in these three areas.

 

Broader impact:

The broader impacts of the educational activities conducted in this project included the training of graduate and undergraduate students, providing research experience to middle-school and high-school science teachers, integration of research activities into the teaching of science and engineering at the K-12, undergraduate, and graduate levels, involvement of under-represented students in research activities, and development and broad dissemination of research-based educational materials. This work supported all of part of the education of a number of Ph.D. students. One Ph.D. student funded exclusively by this work completed his Ph.D. degree and a second Ph.D. student that is primarily funded by this work is anticipated to complete his Ph.D. degree within the next year. Three middle- and high-school science teachers joined the PI’s research groups through RET supplements received for this project during three summers. Through REU supplements received for this project, undergraduate students got an opportunity to get involved with research activities. The technologies developed in this project resulted in two U.S. patents. The findings of this project were also broadly disseminated. In particular, this work resulted in eight journal papers (seven published and one under review) and 8 conference papers. Moreover, the PI has also given five invited talks and seminars related to this project at U.S. and international institutions of higher education, research labs, or corporations.
